scenarioDescription:
The GJ 414 A Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 414 A is a star with 0.65 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.68 times its radius. It is located 38.78 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 12.4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 414 A is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 414 A system


GJ 414 A b

GJ 414 A b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2021-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.40 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 414 A b is 7.603 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 414 A b is 2.630 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 414 A b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 414 A c

GJ 414 A c was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2021-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 414 A c is 53.860 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 414 A c is 8.400 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 414 A c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system GJ 414 A, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: GJ 414 A - System With 2 Exoplanets
